snippet: The financial crisis has given remarkable staying power to false explanations of big events. And they continue to warp policy.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column disputes claims in British news media in run-up to Conservative Party's election triumph that excessive government spending on less fortunate was to blame for country's financial crisis; criticizes George Osborne, chancellor of Exchequer, who has said he plans to make austerity policies permanent; suggests that this is an example of how bad ideas can inexplicably have remarkable staying power, despite their detrimental effects.
lead_paragraph: The financial crisis has given remarkable staying power to false explanations of big events. And they continue to warp policy.
